title: Utilitywise unveils new strategy after resolving accounting challenges
text:

Energy consultancy firm Utilitywise has unveiled a new strategy that aims to add 100,000 customers to its books.
North Tyneside ’s Utilitywise’s new strategy comes as the firm puts behind it a tough 12 months which saw it forced to suspend trading of its shares on the London Stock Exchange because of a delay in publishing its financial accounts.
The firm has now unveiled a new strategy designed to increase its SME market share from 2% to 7% over the next three years. As part of this, the company is looking grow its number of SME customers from 30,000 to 130,000.
It will also attempt to win a 5% share of the UK and Ireland corporate controls market by July 2021. Utilitywise CEO, Brendan Flattery
Brendan Flattery, chief executive officer of Utilitywise, said: “Utilitywise is firmly focused on significantly increasing its market share by broadening its target market and the services it provides its customers, in order to drive returns for shareholders. That means the company will have to evolve its proposition and channel strategy, as detailed above, while optimising operational productivity.
“The strategy update outlined today will enable Utilitywise to meet its two new financial targets, as well as maximising the medium term potential from the business.”
Utilitywise’s enterprise division’s strategy comprises four key points, with the most noticeable focusing on the use of a price comparison website.
The website already exists but is working at, what the firm describes as, “a relatively modest scale”. However, the company is planning to increase its investment in the service during the 2018/19 financial year. Read More Business Secretary makes plea for business-friendly Brexit
The other key points include: improving efficiencies and optimising its sales channels; offering additional utilities; and improving its cross sales.
Utilitywise’s corporate division will also look to develop its strategic partnership, digital buildings, and focus on the evolution of the Internet of Things.
The company recently published its results for the six months ending January 31, which showed a much needed improvement.
During the six months the firm made an operating profit of £617,000, compared with an operating loss of £13.2m during the same period during the previous year. Turnover during the period also grew by 3.5% from £38.4m to £39.7m. Like us on Facebook
